summary: A character reference letter addressed to Judge Alison Nathan in support of Ghislaine Maxwell, written by an unnamed friend. The writer describes Maxwell's kindness in providing free housing in London after the writer's husband died, and asserts belief in Maxwell's innocence.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: The letter is addressed to her as the presiding judge in Ghislaine Maxwell's case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the character reference letter. The writer defends her moral character and asserts her innocence regarding the charges against her.

connections.description: Friends for over 25 years. Maxwell provided free housing to the writer in London during a time of financial and personal crisis.
The writer's husband was an old friend of Ghislaine Maxwell, having met her first in Hong Kong in the early 1990s.
Old friends who first met in Hong Kong in the early 1990s.

events.title: Character Reference Submission
events.description: A friend of Ghislaine Maxwell submits a character reference letter to Judge Alison Nathan in support of Maxwell.

events.title: Death of Writer's Husband
events.description: The letter writer's husband died approximately three years prior to December 2020, leaving the writer destitute and homeless.

events.title: Meeting in Hong Kong
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell first met the letter writer's husband in Hong Kong.

locations: London, England (location of Ghislaine Maxwell's home where the writer stayed)
Hong Kong (location where Maxwell first met the writer's husband in the early 1990s)
New York, NY 10007 (location of the United States Courthouse at 40 Foley Square)
Countryside in England (location of the writer's mother's house)
keyFacts: The document is a character reference letter submitted to the court in support of Ghislaine Maxwell in December 2020.
The writer, a friend of Maxwell for over 25 years, states that Maxwell provided her with free housing in London after the writer's husband died, leaving her destitute.
The writer asserts her belief that Ghislaine Maxwell is innocent of the charges against her and deserves due process and humane treatment.
The letter reveals a social connection between Maxwell and the writer's husband dating back to a meeting in Hong Kong in the early 1990s.
